Inst_Author: 003101 - University of San Carlos. Institute of Research and Higher Education|000775 - Michigan State University
Title: Programa interuniversitario of the University of San Carlos, Guatemala, and Michigan State University; final evaluation report

Abstract: EVALUATES PROJ PERFORMANCE AS OF 10/65 IN MOROCCO.  PURPOSE OF PROJ WAS TO BRING ABOUT THE IRRIGATION OF APPROX 176000 ACRES OF FARMLAND AND THE INTRODUCTION OF SOUND IRRIG FARMING PRACTICES IN THE TARGET AREA. US DEPT OF AGR/US DEPT OF INT ERIOR STUDY TEAM OBTAINED THE INFORMATION FOR THIS EVAL THROUGH INTERVIEWS WITH GOM, USAID, US EMBASSY, UN, AND HYDROTECHNIC CORP OFFICIALS;ON-SITE OBSERV AT TARGET AREA FARMS;AND DISCUSSIONS WITH FARMERS AND THE STAFF MEMBERS OF THE EXPERIMENT STATIONS, LIVESTOCK BREEDING STATIONS, PROCESSING PLANTS & THE PERIMETER (PROJ AREA) HEADQUARTERS OF BOTH THE TADLA AND LOWER MOULOUYA PROJS. ALTHOUGH AT TIME OF EVAL ONLY 32000 ACRES HAD BEEN BROUGHT UNDER IRRIG,THE FUTURE OF THE PROJ,GIVEN ADEQUATE FUNDING,APPEARED FAVORABLE.IT WAS DETERMND THAT: THE GOM PLACES A HIGH PRIORITY ON THE ACHIEVEMENT OF PROJ GOALS; GOM PLANS FOR THE DEVEL OF THIS PROJ ARE FEASIBLE & EFFECTIVE; COMPLETED CONSTRUCTION FOR THE PROJ IS OF HIGH QUALITY; THERE ARE SUFFICIENT WATER RESOURCES FOR THE TARGET AREA AND THE SOIL QUALITY OF AREA IS GENERALLY GOOD; UPPER-LVL GOMPERSNNL ASSIGNED TO PROJ ARE WELL-QUALIFIED; AND THE TARGET FARMERS ARE PERHAPS THE BEST IN MOROCCO. THERE DID APPEAR TO BE A SHORTAGE OF QUALIFIED GOM PERSNNL AT THE PERIMETER LEVEL;GOM HAS RESPONDED TO THIS THROUGH PERSNNL CHANGES. IT IS RECOMMENDED: 1)FEAS STUDIES OF THE TRIFFA & GAREB PLAIN BE POSTPONED UNTIL MORE IS KNOWN OF THE WATER SUPPLY IN THOSE AREAS; 2)STUDY SHOULD BE CNDUCTED TO DETERMINE HOW TO PROTEC T THE MECHRA KLILA RESERVOIR FROM FILLING WITH SEDIMENT; 3)ANNUAL COMMITMENTS FROM THE NEW LOAN (TO COMPLETE PROJ)SHOULD BE DETERMINED BY PROGRESS ACHIEVED BY GOM IN MEETING PROJ SCHEDULE; 4)MANPOWER SURVEY SHOULD BE CONDUCTED OF THE AVAILABILITY & NEEDS OF AGR TECHS DURING THE NEXT 5 YRS; 5)SUBSTANTIVE IN-SRVC TRNG PROGS BE IMPLEMENTED FOR GOM PROJ PERSNNL; 6)US TECHS SHOULD BE USED AS CONSULTANTS; NUMBER OF FOREIGN TECHS IN OPER POSITIONS BE HELD TO A MINIMUM; 7)UNIRRIG PROJ AREA GRASSLANDS SHOULD BE SEEDED & HAVE CONTROLLED GRAZING; 8)BRANCH OF ECON & STATS BE ESTBLSHD AT HQ'S LAND DEVEL DIV; 9)MODEL CMV BE ESTBLSHD IN LOWER MOUL AREA.

Title: EVALUATION AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR MOULOUYA IRRIGATION PROJECT OF MOROCCO (8/65-10/65)

Abstract: Evaluates project performance from 3/30/62 to 6/30/65 in Peru. Program assists Govt of Peru (GOP) to increase knowledge, skills & capabilities of its populatn through the establishmt of a total educatnal program.  Evaluatn methodology not defined. A great deal has been accomplished in GOP's attempt to upgrade educatnal skills.  Columbia Univ (CU) has provided Peru's Ministry of Educatn (MOE) with educatnal planning assist, inservice & pre-service teacher training, curriculum & teaching materials for the Developmt Center, technical and/or educational services, constructn & equipmt acquisitn, and overseas training for 32 Peruvian educators.  With CU assistance, MOE worked out plans to improve educational programs through primary, secondary, technical, and industrial educational systems; community devel; educational admin; scholarship programs; and educational evaluatn. Team members have visited all types of schools, analyzed instructn methods & materials, and studied building constructn.  Team has also engaged in orientatn activities; assisted MOE develop its 5 year educational plan & organize a scholarship program; and conducted training sessions for educators.  USAID has exhibited understanding of Peru's educatnal difficulties & offered MOE timely suggestns. Despite progress, improvemt is slow, since Peru's literacy rate at program's inceptn was only 50%; skilled & semi skilled personnel were lacking.  The frequent changes in administrative personnel, poor laws or failure to implemt useful laws on the books & insufficient funds are a constant obstacle.  Other probs have been CU team member's inability to communicate in Spanish and quickly assess cultural & governmental motivatns. Evaluator feels Peru's educational solutn depends on its ability to provide adequate technical assistance, and persuade its private sector to provide funds & training.  Since MOE's requests are too extensive to be accomplished by a staff of 10 technicians, these needs should be realisticly revised according to major priorities.

Title: TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECT HISTORY AND ANALYSIS REPORT

Abstract: EVALUATES PROJECT TO ASSIST THE GOVERNMENT OF LIBERIA (GOL) DEVELOP A PROFESSIONAL AND HIGHER EDUCATIONAL SYSTEM AT THE UNIVERSITY OF LIBERIA (UL) FROM 6/64 TO 12/64. CONTRACTOR /(CORNELL UNIV) HAS A CLEAR UNDERSTANDING OF THE SCOPE AND NATURE OF CONTRACT OBJECTIVES AND HAS SUBMITTED ALLL REQUESTED INFORMATION TO THE GOL IN A TIMELY MANNER. ATTEMPTS ARE BEING MADE TO STRENGHTEN THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN UL AND CORNELL UNIV (CU) AND TO MODIFY THE STAFFING PATTERN. UL HAS MADE GREATER PROGRESS IN THE PAST 2 YEARS THAN IN ANY PREVIOUS DECADE DUE TO THE EXCELLENT ASSISTANCE OF CU AND LEADERSHIP OF UL'S CHIEF OF PARTY. UL'S PARTICIPANT TRAINING PROGRAM AND ON-THE-JOB TRAINING CONDUCTED BY CU TEAM IS PREPARING LIBERIAN STAFF AND FACULTY TO REPLACE CU MEMBERS AND TO IMPROVE UL ADMINISTRATION PRACTICES. SU IS IN TURN BEING INCLUDED IN MORE DECISION MAKING ACTIVITIES. GOOD EXAMPLES SET BY THE EUROPEAN AND AMERICAN FACULTY AND STAFF MEMBERS (50% OF UL STAFF) ARE INFLUENCING THE LIBERIAN UL PERSONNEL TO SHOW MORE INITIATIVE AND FOLLOW BETTER WORK HABITS. UL FUNDING HAS BEEN INCREASED, WHICH ALLOWS PRESENT PROGRAMS TO BE EXPANDED AND IMPROVED. IT IS HOPED THAT INCREASES IN THE NUMBER OF SCHOLARSHIPS AND DORMITORY FACILITIES FOR PROMISING STUDENTS WILL ENCOURAGE A LARGER NUMBER OF QUALIFIED LIBERIAN STUDENTS TO ENROLL AT UL. ARRANGEMENTS ARE BEING MADE TO HAVE LIBERIAN COUNTERPARTS TO THE CU TEAM EDUCATED AND TRAINED IN THE US. THESE COUNTERPARTS WILL REPLACE THE CU TEAM MEMBERS AFTER PROJECT IS TERMINATED. MAJOR OBSTACLES STILL NEEDING IMPROVEMENT ARE: 1)DEVELOPING A SYSTEM FOR IMPROVING BUILDINGS AND GROUNDS PLANNING,MAINTENANCE,ETC; 2)ESTABLISHING OF PERSONNEL POLICIES AND PROFICIENCY RATINGS; 3)IMPROVING ADMINISTRATIVE PRACTICES AND UNIVERSITY BOARD OF TRUSTEE PERFORMANCE; 4)REDICING POLITICAL INFLUENCES IN UL DECISION MAKING,AND 5)DECREASING GO;'S SLOWNESS IN RESPONDING TO CU REQUEST.
Descriptors_Topical: On the job training|FACULTY|Universities and colleges|Educational administration|Higher education|Educational development|Technical training
Title: PROFESSIONAL AND HIGHER EDUCATION

Abstract: This report assesses how well this particular program was operating and suggests improvements in future efforts.  The study was based on data obtained through personal interviews and written questionnaires completed by 90 participants who had returned to India following U.S. training.  Many specific recommendations are contained in the report in the areas of training design, selection of participants, support services, follow-up, utilization of training, and professional development.  (Author abstract)
Inst_Author: 004160 - University of Tennessee. College of Agriculture
Title: Special report : an evaluation of participant training under the University of Tennessee - India agricultural program

Abstract: This report, one of 23 country studies conducted as part of a wordlwide survey, reviews A.I.D.'s participant training program in British Honduras (now Belize) from 1953 to 1963.  The report was based on interviews with 78 of 98 returned participants, as well as with 39 supervisors and two U.S. technicians. Recommendations address the areas of training design, pre-departure preparation, support services, follow-up, and the utilization of training.  (Author abstract, modified)
Title: Participant training program in British Honduras, 1953-1963 : report of an evaluation survey

Abstract: This final report presents the findings from the worldwide evaluation of the conduct and effects of the USAID Participant Training Program. This is BSSR's submission to A.I.D. of findings based on twenty-three country studies from which the final A.I.D. report was published the following year. (Participant training abstract)
Inst_Author: 004163 - Bur. for Social Science Research, Inc.
Title: Participant training program : an evaluative survey

Abstract: This report is one of twenty-three country studies conducted as part of the worldwide survey of returned participants in accordance with AID/W instructions and guidelines contained in ICATO Circular A-175, November 1959.  The major purpose of this global effort was to obtain an overview of how the participant training program was progressing to ascertain ways in which future training might be more effective at the country, AID/W, and training institution levels.  The study involved 249 Jordanian participants who were interviewed along with 25 supervisors and 13 U.S. technicians.  Many specific recommendations are made on training design, location of training and pre-departure preparation, English language, orientation, support services, follow-up, and utilization of training. (Participant training abstract)
